output.conclusion: This course provides a comprehensive understanding of electric circuits, equipping students with the knowledge and skills necessary for advanced applications in electrical engineering.
output.introduction: Welcome to Advanced Electric Circuits! This course delves into the intricacies of circuit analysis and design, building upon foundational knowledge to explore complex concepts and practical applications.

chapters.description: Explore modified nodal analysis (MNA) and its application to circuits with dependent sources and operational amplifiers. Learn about sparse matrix techniques for efficient circuit simulation.
Apply superposition to circuits with multiple independent and dependent sources. Analyze circuits with non-linear elements using piecewise linear approximations.
Determine Thevenin and Norton equivalents for complex circuits with dependent sources and operational amplifiers. Apply these theorems to simplify circuit analysis and design.
Analyze the transient response of RLC circuits with different damping conditions (overdamped, critically damped, underdamped). Determine the step response and impulse response of these circuits.
Develop state-space models for electric circuits. Analyze the stability and controllability of circuits using state-space techniques.

chapters.chapterTitle: Laplace Transform Techniques in Circuit Analysis
chapters.description: Apply Laplace transforms to solve circuit problems in the s-domain. Analyze the frequency response of circuits using Laplace transforms.
Define and calculate two-port network parameters (Z, Y, H, T). Analyze the interconnection of two-port networks.
Design passive and active filters (low-pass, high-pass, band-pass, band-stop) using Butterworth, Chebyshev, and Bessel approximations.
Explore advanced filter topologies such as switched-capacitor filters and active-RC filters. Analyze the performance of these filters.
Analyze the effects of non-ideal op-amp characteristics (input bias current, input offset voltage, finite gain) on circuit performance.
Design and analyze circuits using op-amps for instrumentation amplifiers, active filters, and precision rectifiers.
Analyze the stability of feedback amplifiers using Bode plots and Nyquist plots. Design compensation techniques to improve amplifier stability.
